problems.question: What is the mathematical form of the radioactive decay law for number of nuclei \(N(t)\)?
problems.hint: Decay causes exponential decrease; the exponent is negative.
problems.detailed: The radioactive decay law states that the number of undecayed nuclei decreases exponentially: \(N(t) = N_0 e^{-\lambda t}\), where \(\lambda\) is the decay constant.
problems.author: Mubarak Aouda

problems.question: Which equation correctly relates the half-life \(t_{1/2}\) and the decay constant \(\lambda\)?
problems.hint: Half-life is inversely proportional to the decay constant.
problems.detailed: The relationship is \(t_{1/2} = \frac{\ln 2}{\lambda}\). This comes from setting \(N(t_{1/2}) = \tfrac12 N_0\) in the exponential law.
problems.author: Mubarak Aouda

problems.question: If a radioactive sample has a half-life of 10 years, what fraction of the original nuclei remains after 10 years?
problems.detailed: After one half-life, exactly half (1/2) of the original nuclei remain. So the correct fraction is 1/2.
problems.author: Mubarak Aouda

problems.question: What happens to the activity \(A\) of a radioactive sample over time (assuming no new nuclei added)?
problems.hint: Activity is proportional to the number of remaining nuclei.
problems.detailed: Activity \(A\) is proportional to the number of undecayed nuclei, so as \(N(t)\) decreases exponentially, the activity also decreases exponentially following \(A(t)=\lambda N(t)\).
problems.author: Mubarak Aouda

problems.question: Which of these is true about the decay constant \(\lambda\)?
options: It depends on the initial amount of the sample
problems.hint: It is a probability per unit time.
problems.detailed: The decay constant \(\lambda\) is the probability per unit time that a given nucleus will decay; hence its units are inverse time (e.g. \(s^{-1}\)). It is independent of sample size and external conditions.
problems.author: Mubarak Aouda
